prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Glycine at 212.3 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Glycine conformer I at 212.3 GHz (J=36-35, K=0)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Since G10.47+0.03 is a molecule-rich source, it is desired to observe as many other molecular lines as possible for understanding the chamical evelution ongoing in this source. We have chosen another weaker Glycine transition (J=35-34, K=1) as well as the primary target (Glycine J=36-35, K=0) for better unserdtand the excitation temperature of Glycine, if detected. Molecular lines from G10.47+0.03 have a linewidth of about 8 km/s. Therefore a frequency resolution of 488 kHz (corresponding to the velocity resolution of 0.69 km/s) would be sufficent to resolve the line shape.
Basebands 3 and 4 will be used to determine the continuum level at around 214 GHz by using line-free regions. If detected, this wll enable us to discuss spatial relationship between the glycine emission lines and spatial distribution of (dust) continuum.

The sublimation temperature of Glycine is about 200 K, suggesting the source size is compact with a size of a few arcseconds or less. Thus an angular resolution of 1.5 arcsecond would be sufficient.
Cesaroni et al. (2010) reported a mapping observation in the NH3 (4,4) line towards G10.47+0.03; the NH3 emission extends up to 4-5 arcseconds. Thus we may expect similar angular size as the largest angular scale to be imaged.

The expected line intensity is 116 mK, as is shown in the Science Justification. Molecular lines from G10.47+0.03 have a linewidth of about 8 km/s. Therefore a frequency resolution of 488 kHz (corresponding to the velocity resolution of 0.69 km/s) would be sufficent to resolve the line shape. Since the line is not so strong, it is needed to observe the line with at least 4 times the RMS noise level. Thus we would like to integrate the noise fluctuation down to 25 mK with the channel spacing of 244 kHz (a half of the frequency resolution).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe G10.47+0.03 with six lines of Glycine (NH2CH2COOH) in the Band 6. We have found that G10.47+0.03 has the richest abundance of methylamine (CH3NH2), a presursor to glycine. The first detection of glycine would be plausible with the corresponding abundance of glycine calculated by Garrod (2013). Furthermore G10.47+0.03 shows narrower linewidth than Sgr B2(N). Thus smaller probability of line contamination would be expected.
Once successful, we will be able to open a new era of astrochemistry and astrobiology in that many researchers would join in finding other amino acids and/or other prebiotic molecules.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Data Center, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
